bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, January 29, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests permission to examine Agramonte's papers during his next trip to Havana. He assures Rodriguez Leon that he wants to give due credit to her father's work. Hench is trying to identify the location depicted in the photograph that she loaned to him.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, January 29, 1941

January 29, 1941
Senora Estella Rodriguez-Leon
15 Street No. 311
Vedado, Havana
Cuba
My dear Senora Rodriguez-Leon:
div1.p:
I plan to return to Havana the last two weeks in March and
sincerely hope that I will be able to visit you again. By separate post,
I am sending you a brochure which was just published, and which included
my Washington and Jefferson talk with quotations from you. I have
collected quite a lot of data concerning the yellow fever experiments, so
much so that I have been urged by several interested parties to publish
a monograph thereon. I am therefore most anxious to obtain further help
from you when I visit you. I believe that for the sake of your father's
memory you will wish to give me this help because unfortunately, I have found
certain persons in this country who rather belittle your father's contri-
bution toward the work. A perusal of your father's papers has convinced me
that he did much more work than he was given credit for, but I need proof
in the form of such letters and papers, and perhaps diary, that you may
possess. Do you think it would be at all possible for you to visit the
house where much of your material is stored and to have it available for me
to look over in March?

I realize that the time I spend in Havana may not be sufficient
for me to study it carefully even with your help, but perhaps with your per-
mission I can have some of it copied and some of it photostated. I can assure
you my only thought is to give due credit to all concerned, most assuredly
including your father, and before publishing anything about your father, I
absolutely promise to submit it to you for your comments and criticism.

Enclosed please find the last photograph you so kindly loaned
me. I have been trying to get it identified. I have sent it to General
Truby who was commanding officer at the Post Hospital in 1900 and also to
General Kean, whom you remember. Neither of these man can identify the loca-
tion but I have had the photograph copied and will keep sending it to various
survivors in the hope that somebody can identify it. Among other things, you
remember I asked your permission to photostate the entire manuscript of your
father's unpublished address. You only sent me one page to photostat. I re-
turn it with my deepest thanks.

It will be indeed a pleasure to meet you and your good husband
again and I promise not to bother you any more than your goodness will permit,
but I know that you will want your father's share in the conquest of yellow
fever properly presented.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
